title: A New Method to Represent the Harmonic Measurement Accuracy of Current Transformers
abstract: Metrological performance of current transformers (CTs) is typically quantified in terms of ratio and phase errors. While they provide a good picture at the fundamental component, they are not as effective in condensing the accuracy of harmonic measurements in the presence of nonlinearity. This article proposes a new approach derived from the Volterra representation of the CT. The complex error has been adopted as the accuracy metric, split into a deterministic contribution (purely correlated with the measurand) and a circularly symmetric random term, whose spread depends on the fundamental magnitude; moreover, the proposed approach boils down to the usual ratio and phase errors if the CT exhibits negligible nonlinearity. The effectiveness of the developed method has been tested on an inductive CT, as a typical current transducer suffering from nonlinearity; nevertheless, results can be deemed as general since the approach has been derived from a behavioral model of the CT, and thus, independent of its operating principle. The impact of both measurement disturbances and uncertainty introduced by the nonideal calibration of the test setup has been also evaluated.

A New Method to Represent the Harmonic 
Measurement Accuracy of Current Transformers  
 
Marco Faifer, Senior Member, IEEE, Christian Laurano, Member, IEEE, Roberto Ottoboni, Fellow, IEEE,  
and Sergio Toscani, Senior Member, IEEE
 
Abstract—Metrological performance of current transformers 
(CTs) is typically quantified in terms of ratio and phase errors. 
While they provide a good picture at the fundamental, they are not 
as effective in condensing the accuracy of harmonic measurements 
in the presence of nonlinearity. This article proposes a new 
approach, derived from the Volterra representation of the CTs. 
The complex error has been adopted as accuracy metric, split into 
a deterministic contribution (purely correlated with the 
measurand) and a circularly symmetric random term, whose 
spread depends on the fundamental magnitude. Moreover, the 
proposed approach boils down to the usual ratio and phase errors 
if the CT exhibits negligible nonlinearity. The effectiveness of the 
developed method has been tested on an inductive CT, as a typical 
current transducer suffering from nonlinearity. Nevertheless, 
results can be deemed as general, since the approach has been 
derived from a behavioral model of the CT, thus independent from 
its operating principle. The impact of both measurement 
disturbances and uncertainty introduced by the non-ideal 
calibration of the test setup has been also evaluated. 
 
Index Terms— current measurement, current transformers, 
instrument transformers, measur ement uncertainty, nonlinear 
systems, power system harmonics. 
I. INTRODUCTION 
URING the last decade, we experienced a massive 
diffusion of  nonlinear, power electronic-based devices 
in distribution grids. This trend is likely to continue, 
and possibly further grow in the years to come, driven 
by the decarbonization process and the development of electric 
mobility. From a power quality (PQ) point of view [1], the 
harmonic distortion [2] of current and voltage waveforms is 
expected to further increase [3]. On the one hand, this is the 
direct consequence of the higher penetration of harmonic-
generating devices. On the other hand, the capacitive filters of 
such power electronic-based devices lower the resonant 
frequencies of the grid, thus resulting in a stronger transfer of 
low-order harmonics [4]. Moreover, the high-frequency content 
is going to grow, because of the increasing switching 
frequencies adopted by the manufacturers. This incoming 
scenario boosts the importance of PQ assessment; in this 
respect, instrument transformers (ITs) play a key role [5], [6]. 
In this paper, the focus is moved towards harmonic 
disturbances, representing one of the most severe power quality 
phenomena [2], responsible for lower efficiency, increased 
thermal and dielectric stresses and for the triggering of

resonances. In this respect, advanced monitoring of harmonics 
allows detecting critical situations and, together with proper 
techniques, identifying the most polluting users [7]. 
Furthermore, it would permit reconstructing the harmonic state 
of the grid [8], enabling a detailed analysis of the propagation 
of disturbances [9], as well as an effective study of corrective 
actions. Methods have been developed to limit the number of 
the monitored nodes [10], thus reducing cost and complexity of 
the infrastructure. 
The significance of the results strongly depends on the 
quality of the available data: knowing the level of 
trustworthiness has multifold importance. Firstly, it permits 
estimating the confidence level of the outcome, which is key 
when it influences critical decisions. Furthermore, it enables the 
most effective exploitation of the available information: to be 
more specific, it would be possible to tune the dependency of 
the estimate on each incoming measurement so that it reflects 
its uncertainty level, as in the weighted least squares approach. 
Finally, it greatly helps an effective design and development of 
the monitoring infrastructure.  
The accuracy of harmonic measurements depends on the 
adopted technique (e.g., the algorithm allowing to extract the 
harmonic phasors), but, as aforementioned, it is heavily affected 
by the ITs. Their overall performance is summarized by the 
accuracy class [11]. As far as the conventional voltage 
transformers (VTs) for metering applications, [12] specifies 
maximum ratio and phase errors at the fundamental, assumed 
to fall within 80 % and 120 % of its rated value. The same 
approach is adopted for low-power voltage transformers 
(LPVTs) [13].  
Accuracy requirements for VTs devoted to harmonic 
measurements consist of ratio and phase errors limits that 
increase with frequency [11]. However, when considering 
inductive VTs, it has been shown that providing a ratio and 
phase error value for each harmonic does represent an effective 
way to express accuracy [14]. The main reason is the nonlinear 
behavior due to the iron core [15], making that the superposition 
principle no longer holds. The measurement of harmonics, 
whose frequencies are multiple of the fundamental, suffers from 
harmonic distortion (HD) and intermodulation (IM) effects 
produced by the (weakly) nonlinear input-output characteristic 
[16]. These considerations apply also to LPVTs, which may be 
affected by nonlinear phenomena.

Different challenges are faced when measuring currents, 
claiming for a different way to express the performance 
achieved by current transformers (CTs). Firstly, the harmonic 
content of currents could be significantly stronger than that of 
voltages. Then, under regular operation, their magnitudes may 
vary over a much broader range. Therefore, standards [17], [18] 
concerning conventional and low-power CTs (LPCTs) set 
accuracy requirements at the fundamental component in a 
different way with respect to VTs and LPVTs. In fact, for a 
given accuracy class, they prescribe ratio and phase error limits 
down to at least 5 % of the rated primary current. These limits 
increase noticeably at lower currents; implicitly, this takes into 
account nonlinearity occurring in inductive CTs [19], [20], but 
also in some LPCTs, depending on the operating principle. 
As far as harmonic measurements, accuracy requirements for 
CTs are identical as those of VTs [11], thus consisting of phase 
and ratio error limits that increase with the harmonic order, but 
they do not depend on the level of the measured component. In 
this respect, [18] somehow admits that the present solution is 
not fully satisfactory, stating that “…the improvement of the 
relevant test procedures given there is under consideration by 
IEC TC 38”. 
In this scenario, [21] investigated through numerical 
simulations the behavior of ratio and phase errors of an 
inductive CT when it is employed to measure harmonics. 
Results show that their values are scattered over a very wide 
range, and the spread strongly depends on the relative 
magnitude of the harmonic to be measured with respect to the 
fundamental. In particular, the smaller the relative harmonic 
amplitude is, the broader the scattering is. This is clearly not 
consistent with how the relevant standards prescribe accuracy 
requirements at the harmonics. The reason lays, once again, in 
the nonlinear behavior of the CT, which makes that the mere 
ratio and phase error values are not capable of properly 
expressing accuracy at a given harmonic order, leading to either 
a severe underestimation or overestimation. 
The present article, which is the technical extension of [21], 
investigates and proposes an alternative and more effective 
method to properly represent the accuracy of harmonic current 
measurements through concise indexes, also in the presence of 
nonlinearity. The approach arises from a behavioral modeling 
of the CT based on the Volterra approach. Abstracting from its 
operating principle, the CT is treated as a weakly nonlinear time 
invariant (NTI) system subject to periodic primary currents 
having realistic spectral content. The outcome of the analysis 
suggests adopting the complex error as accuracy metric, which 
in turn is split into a deterministic and a stochastic contribution. 
The first one is, by definition, purely related (proportional) to 
the measurand. The second is produced by the HD and IM 
generated by the CT, consisting of a circularly symmetric 
random variable whose spread increases with the fundamental 
magnitude. The parameters describing the behavior of the two 
contributions can be easily computed from the experimental 
data using the least-squares (LS) approach. Moreover, the 
proposed method can be considered as the generalization of the 
usual practice of rating the ratio and phase error, so that 
nonlinear effects are properly handled. 
Expressions that enable quantifying the impact of 
measurement disturbances and of the uncertain calibration of 
the adopted setup have been derived. They have vital 
importance in confirming the significance of the obtained 
results, but also in designing and improving the experimental 
activity. The approach has been tested on an inductive CT, as a 
typical current transducer suffering from coupled dynamic and 
nonlinear effects. 
II. F
RAMEWORK 
The goal of this paper is proposing a simple yet effective 
method to condense the metrological performance of CTs in 
measuring power systems harmonics, also in the presence of 
nonlinearities. In particular, the approach should abstract from 
the physical operating principle of the CT, so that the result is 
as flexible as possible. This Section presents the tools and the 
framework adopted during the study. It defines the measurand 
(i.e., the harmonic content of primary current waveforms) and 
introduces a general, behavioral representation of the CT.

B. Behavioral Model of CTs 
From a behavioral point of view, a CT can be considered as 
a (weakly) NTI system whose input is i1. Its output y2 is the 
quantity that is processed to extract the primary current 
harmonic phasors. In a conventional inductive CT, y2 
corresponds to the secondary current, but in general it could be 
a voltage or even a discrete-time signal [24]. Under weak 
assumptions, the input-output behavior of an NTI system can 
be represented through the Volterra approach [25]. In this case, 
it can be easily shown that the steady-state response to a 
periodic input is periodic with the same period. Therefore, y
2 
can be expressed as a Fourier series, written in the form (1). The 
expression of the generic hth order harmonic phasor in the 
output Y2(h) can be derived by applying the multivariable

A. Modeling Errors at Fundamental 
Let us investigate the behavior of the complex error (7) at the 
fundamental. Reminding that primary current harmonics are 
considerably smaller than the fundamental, (8) suggests that the 
most significant error contributions due to CT nonlinearity are 
those involving exclusively the fundamental primary current

B. Modeling Errors at Harmonics 
Let us analyze the most relevant complex error contributions 
due to nonlinearity that affect the measurement of I̅1(h), h2. 
As highlighted in Section III-A, the largest ones are expected to

IV. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP 
 The error models introduced in Section III have been derived 
from a behavioral representation of the CT. Therefore, they are 
general with respect to the physical operating principle and 
capable of considering coupled filtering and nonlinear effects. 
The inductive CT is a typical current transducer that suffers 
from the aforementioned phenomena; thus, it represents a 
suitable candidate for studying approaches aimed at condensing 
its metrological performance in the most effective way. For this 
reason, tests have been carried out on a class 0.5 inductive CT 
with 10 VA rated burden, nominal ratio K
n=50 A/5 A and f0=50 
Hz nominal frequency.  
The experimental activity requires injecting periodic primary 
current waveforms belonging to class , sampling the primary 
and secondary waveforms under steady state conditions, 
extracting the harmonic phasors and processing the data. The 
schematic diagram of the adopted experimental setup is 
reported in Fig. 1. It resembles the architecture of the current 
generator presented in [30].  
 
Fig. 1.  Schematic diagram of the experimental setup. 
The CT under test, feeding the rated burden, is supplied by an 
AETechron 7548 power amplifier connected to a transformer to 
increase its maximum output current. Primary and secondary 
currents are measured by means of calibrated coaxial shunts 
having 20 kHz bandwidth and rated currents of 100 A and 10 A, 
respectively. The power amplifier input voltage is provided by 
a National Instruments USB-6356 multifunction I/O device, 
also used to acquire the primary and secondary current 
waveforms. It features 16-bit resolution, 1.25 MSample/s 
maximum rate per channel (simultaneous sampling), 
synchronized generation and sampling capability. Analog 
Devices AD215BY isolation amplifiers in noninverting 
configuration (100 nominal gain) have been adopted to magnify 
the output voltages of the coaxial shunts, thus enabling a better 
exploitation of the range of the analog input channels. Their 
frequency responses have been measured and compensated in 
the frequency domain. After calibration, considering 
frequencies up to 1.5 kHz, the residual mismatches between 
magnitude and phase errors of the two current measurement 
channels are below 200 ppm and 0.2 mrad, respectively. 
Finally, the accuracy of current generation has been 
improved by measuring the frequency response function 
between the power amplifier input and the injected primary 
current, while pre-compensating the waveforms to be 
generated. 
V. 
 EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS 
A. Test Procedure 
The experimental setup described in Section IV has been used 
to feed the CT under test with a set of R=2000 primary current 
waveforms belonging to class , thus obtained by sampling the 
PDFs defined in Section II-A, considering harmonic orders up 
to 32. For each reference signal, once steady-state has been 
reached, the corresponding primary and secondary current 
waveforms have been measured with rate fs=200 kHz. Since 
fs/f0 is integer, thanks to the synchronous generation and 
sampling capability of the adopted setup, exactly P=100 periods 
have been acquired. Considering each rth waveform and pth 
period, primary and secondary current harmonic phasors 
I̅1,[r,p](h) and I̅2,[r,p](h) (up to the 30th order) have been extracted 
through DFT without leakage phenomena. For the sake of 
convenience, their magnitudes will be expressed in per units 
with respect to the rated primary and secondary currents of the 
CT under test. 
These phasor measurements are clearly subject to the 
uncertainties introduced by the nonideal calibration of the 
primary and secondary current measurement chains that, in this 
case, comprise a shunt, an isolation amplifier, a data acquisition 
channel. These uncertainties can be modeled with unknown 
magnitude and phase errors that, for each harmonic order, 
depend on neither r, nor p. 
Evaluated primary and secondary side phasors are also 
subject to measurement disturbances, which have been 
considered as additive complex-valued random contributions 
having circularly symmetric PDFs. In this case, their second-
order statistics is fully expressed by their (real-valued) 
variances and a (complex-valued) covariance [29]. The 
presence of such disturbances makes that, for a given hth 
harmonic order, the P phasors measured in each acquired period 
of the same current waveform are different. Their impact can be 
mitigated by estimating the primary and secondary hth order 
harmonic phasors I̅
1,[r](h) and I̅2,[r](h) by averaging over the P 
acquired periods of the rth excitation signal. Under the 
aforementioned assumptions, the variances and covariance of 
of I̅1,[r](h) and I̅2,[r](h) due to measurement disturbances can be 
estimated as

According to the considerations carried out in Section III-A, 
ξ̅r,D(1) depends on the adopted ratio and it includes all the 
strongest nonlinear terms (namely the elements of b(1)), 
purely related to the fundamental. ξ̅r,S(1) is due to the weaker 
nonlinear terms that belongs to c(1), hence it is expected to be 
much smaller.   
In order to carry out the study, it is important to identify a 
strategy to separate ξ̅r,D(1) from ξ̅r,S(1). An attractive possibility 
is performing a LS fitting of the relative complex error data 
ξ̅r,[r](1) with a proper parametric model for ξ̅r,D(1). In general, 
the effectiveness of the procedure depends on the amount of 
available data and on the capability of the selected model to 
fully capture the behavior of ξ̅r,D(1) through a concise set of 
parameters. ξ̅r,S(1) acts as a superimposed zero-mean noise with 
circularly symmetric PDF [29]. Moreover, the LS solution has 
a strong metrological meaning, since it corresponds to minimize 
the sample variance of the stochastic error ξ̅r,S(1).  
 Reminding Section III-A and the structure of g̅ 1(|I̅1(1)|), one 
may be tempted to represent ξ̅r,D(1) as a linear combination of 
even-degree powers of the fundamental magnitude. However, a 
good fitting mandates for a large number of terms; on the other 
hand, the result may be plagued by significant oscillations, as it 
often happens when adopting a high-degree polynomial model. 
Much better results are achieved if ξ̅
r,D(1) is represented with 
a complex-valued B-spline [31]. With this choice, the 
coefficients can be easily computed through an ordinary LS 
optimization [31] and many tools are available for the purpose. 
The obtained results are shown in Fig. 2. Spline knots have been

According to (6), the real and imaginary parts of ξ̅

be summarized through the deterministic contribution ξ̅r,D(1) of

CONCLUSION AND FINAL REMARKS 
In general, the accuracy of a CT in measuring harmonic 
components cannot be properly quantified by a mere couple of 
ratio and phase errors. The present article has proposed a new 
approach, derived from the Volterra model of the CT subject to 
periodic primary current waveforms that resembles those 
typically found in distribution grids.  
The complex error is adopted as accuracy figure, with the 
target of parametrizing a circular region in the complex plane 
where the actual harmonic phasor is likely to be for a given 
confidence level.  Such complex error is decomposed into a 
deterministic and a stochastic contribution that, in spite of the 
mathematical passages aimed at studying their statistical 
properties, can be easily separated through a LS-based method. 
The deterministic term is, by definition, purely related to the 
phasor to be measured. For each harmonic, it is expressed by a 
unique complex-valued number; its real and imaginary parts 
virtually correspond to deterministic magnitude and phase 
errors, respectively. The stochastic term is produced by 
nonlinearity, and it exhibits a circularly symmetric PDF; the 
spread of its magnitude becomes broader as the fundamental 
amplitude increases. A proper quantification of this second 
contribution can be performed by rating the 95
th percentile 
value of its magnitude for different ranges of the fundamental 
amplitude. It is worth highlighting that, if the CT were perfectly 
linear (and having neglected measurement disturbances), the 
magnitude of the stochastic contribution would be zero. In this 
case, the proposed approach degrades in the usual magnitude 
and phase error for each harmonic. 
The impact of measurement disturbances and of the 
uncertainty of the calibration setup on the evaluated 
contributions has been quantified. On the one hand, it enables 
assessing the significance of the results. From the opposite 
point of view, it helps determining the specifications of the test 
setup for a given target uncertainty. 
The effectiveness of the method has been validated on an 
inductive CT, notably characterized by mostly odd-degree 
nonlinearity. Nevertheless, achieved results can be deemed as 
general, since the method is based on a behavioral model of the 
CT, thus independent from its operating principle. The 
proposed approach has multifold practical applications: other 
than representing a good tradeoff between complexity and 
fidelity in representing the metrological behavior of a CT, it 
provides valuable inputs for improving the relevant standards, 
in particular revising how accuracy requirements for harmonic 
measurements are prescribed. Moreover, it can be adopted in 
numerical simulations to include a realistic representation of 
errors introduced by CTs. This may help studying harmonic 
state estimation techniques or methods for detecting harmonic 
sources under more realistic conditions.

Marco Faifer (Senior Member, IEEE) 
was born in Bormio, Italy, in 1978. He 
received the Laurea degree in electronic 
engineering and the Ph.D. degree in 
electrical engineering from the 
Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy, in 
2003 and 2009, respectively. He is 
currently an Associate Professor with the Dipartimento di 
Elettronica, Informazione e Bioingegneria, Politecnico di 
Milano. His scientific activity is mainly concerned with DSP 
techniques and the development of industrial sensors and 
devices for high-voltage measurements. Moreover, he develops 
measurement algorithms for the characterization of electrical 
components and materials. He also works in the field of 
diagnostics for electrical devices. 
Christian Laurano (Member, IEEE) 
was born in Lodi, Italy in 1990. He 
received the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees 
(cum laude) in electrical engineering 
from the Politecnico di Milano, Milan, 
Italy, in 2014 and 2018, respectively. 
From 2018 to 2020, he was a Post-
Doctoral Researcher with the Politecnico di Milano. From 2020 
to 2021, he was with the Measurement and Diagnostic Group, 
Transmission and Distribution Technology Department, RSE 
SpA. He is currently an Assistant Professor with the 
Dipartimento di Elettronica, Informazione e Bioingegneria, 
Politecnico di Milano. His main research interests include 
innovative methods to model and characterize electrical 
transducers, diagnostic techniques devoted to electrical grid 
components, and power quality monitoring. 
 
Roberto Ottoboni (Fellow, IEEE) received 
the Laurea and Ph.D. degrees from the 
Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy, in 1987 
and 1992, respectively. From January 2009 
to December 2012, he was the Chair of the 
Electrical Engineering Department, 
Politecnico di Milano. He is currently a Full 
Professor of Electrical and Electronic 
Measurements with the Dipartimento di Elettronica, 
Informazione e Bioingegneria, Politecnico di Milano. His 
research fields range from the study and analysis of digital 
signal processing techniques for measurement to the study and 
implementation of sensors, transducers, and measurement 
systems for electrical quantities for industrial applications, with 
particular attention to innovative sensors for medium and high 
voltages and high current. 
  
Sergio Toscani (Senior Member, IEEE) 
received the M.Sc. (summa cum laude) and 
the Ph.D. (summa cum laude) degrees in 
electrical engineering from the Politecnico 
di Milano, Italy, in 2007 and 2011, 
respectively. From 2011 to 2020 he was 
Assistant Professor in Electrical and 
Electronic Measurement with the 
Dipartimento di Elettronica, Informazione e Bioingegneria, 
Politecnico di Milano, where he currently serves as an 
Associate Professor. His research activity is mainly focused on 
development and testing of current and voltage transducers, 
measurement techniques for power systems, electrical 
components and systems diagnostics. He is member of the 
IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Society and of the 
IEEE TC-39 - Measurements in Power Systems.
